user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_dma_map:
```c
static int metal_uio_dev_dma_map(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_in,
				 int nents_in,
				 struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int i, j;
	void *vaddr_sg_lo, *vaddr_sg_hi, *vaddr_lo, *vaddr_hi;
	struct metal_io_region *io;

	(void)lbus;
	(void)dir;

	/* Check if the the input virt address is MMIO address */
	for (i = 0; i < nents_in; i++) {
		vaddr_sg_lo = sg_in[i].virt;
		vaddr_sg_hi = vaddr_sg_lo + sg_in[i].len;
		for (j = 0, io = ldev->device.regions;
		     j < (int)ldev->device.num_regions; j++, io++) {
			vaddr_lo = io->virt;
			vaddr_hi = vaddr_lo + io->size;
			if (vaddr_sg_lo >= vaddr_lo &&
			    vaddr_sg_hi <= vaddr_hi) {
				break;
			}
		}
		if (j == (int)ldev->device.num_regions) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "%s,%s: input address isn't MMIO addr: 0x%x,%d.\n",
			__func__, ldev->dev_name, vaddr_sg_lo, sg_in[i].len);
			return -EINVAL;
		}
	}
	if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
	return nents_in;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_dev_dma_map:
struct metal_sg {
	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
...
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
						 of each of the pages in the I/O
						 region */
	size_t			size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
						 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
...
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is modified in this function. Analysis by parameter:
- lbus and dir: only cast to void to suppress unused warnings — not modified.
- ldev: only dereferenced (ldev->device.*) and used to read region info — the pointer itself is not assigned to or changed.
- sg_in: only read via indexing (sg_in[i].virt, sg_in[i].len); the pointer variable sg_in is not assigned to or incremented. Reading/modifying the objects pointed to would be allowed by Rule 17.8, but this code only reads them.
- sg_out: compared to sg_in and passed as destination to memcpy. The memcpy modifies the object(s) pointed to by sg_out, which is explicitly allowed by the rule (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified). The pointer variable sg_out itself is not modified.
- nents_in: used as a loop bound and in size calculation for memcpy — not modified.

All pointer arithmetic in the function is performed on local pointer variables (vaddr_sg_lo, vaddr_sg_hi, vaddr_lo, vaddr_hi), not on the function parameter pointers. Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in this function.
